docs.title: Pantrie Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the Pantrie documentation! Pantrie is a modern household inventory management system designed to help you track food items, manage expiration dates, track allergens, nutritional information, and reduce food waste.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Barcode Scanning: Quickly add items by scanning barcodes, powered by Open Food Facts
  • Multi-Household Support: Manage multiple households with role-based permissions
  • Location Tracking: Organize items by custom locations (fridge, pantry, freezer, etc.)
  • Custom Allergen Tracking: Define household-specific allergens and get automatic warnings
  • Expiration Tracking: Never miss expiration dates with visual indicators
  • Smart Search: Find items quickly with search and filtering
  • Nutrition Information: View detailed nutrition facts from Open Food Facts database

docs.title: Cloudflare Tunnels
docs.text: Cloudflare Tunnels provide a secure way to expose your Pantrie instance to the internet without opening ports on your firewall or dealing with complex networking configurations. This is the recommended method for most home users.

docs.title: What is a Cloudflare Tunnel?
docs.text:
Cloudflare Tunnel creates an encrypted tunnel between your server and Cloudflare's network. Traffic to your domain is routed through Cloudflare's network and then securely tunneled to your server, providing:

  • Security: No need to open inbound firewall ports
  • DDoS Protection: Cloudflare's network protects your origin server
  • SSL/TLS: Automatic HTTPS with Cloudflare's certificates
  • Easy Setup: No complex networking or dynamic DNS required

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A domain name registered with Cloudflare (free tier works)
  • Pantrie running via Docker Compose
  • cloudflared installed on your server

docs.title: 1. Install cloudflared
docs.text:
=== "Ubuntu/Debian"

```bash
# Download and install cloudflared
wget https://github.com/cloudflare/cloudflared/releases/latest/download/cloudflared-linux-amd64.deb
sudo dpkg -i cloudflared-linux-amd64.deb
```

=== "Other Linux"

```bash
# Download the binary
wget https://github.com/cloudflare/cloudflared/releases/latest/download/cloudflared-linux-amd64
sudo mv cloudflared-linux-amd64 /usr/local/bin/cloudflared
sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/cloudflared
```

docs.title: 2. Authenticate with Cloudflare
docs.text:
cloudflared tunnel login

This will open a browser window where you can authorize cloudflared to manage your domain.

docs.title: 3. Create a Tunnel
docs.text:
# Create a new tunnel (replace 'pantrie' with your preferred name)
cloudflared tunnel create pantrie

# Note the Tunnel ID that is displayed - you'll need this

docs.title: 4. Configure the Tunnel
docs.text:
Create a configuration file at ~/.cloudflared/config.yml:

tunnel: <YOUR_TUNNEL_ID>
credentials-file: /home/<YOUR_USERNAME>/.cloudflared/<YOUR_TUNNEL_ID>.json

ingress:
  # Route your domain to the nginx reverse proxy
  - hostname: pantrie.yourdomain.com
    service: http://localhost:80

  # Catch-all rule (required)
  - service: http_status:404

Using Different Ports

If you've changed the nginx port in docker-compose.yml, update the service URL accordingly (e.g., http://localhost:8080)

docs.title: 5. Create DNS Record
docs.text:
cloudflared tunnel route dns <YOUR_TUNNEL_ID> pantrie.yourdomain.com

This creates a CNAME record in Cloudflare DNS pointing your subdomain to the tunnel.

docs.title: 6. Run the Tunnel
docs.text:
Test the tunnel first:

cloudflared tunnel run pantrie

If everything works, install it as a system service:

sudo cloudflared service install
sudo systemctl start cloudflared
sudo systemctl enable cloudflared

docs.title: 7. Update Vite Configuration
docs.text:
Update your frontend/vite.config.ts to allow your custom domain:

server: {
  port: 5173,
  host: '0.0.0.0',
  allowedHosts: [
    'localhost',
    '127.0.0.1',
    'pantrie.yourdomain.com',  // Add your domain
    '.yourdomain.com',         // Allow all subdomains
  ],
  // ... rest of config
}

Restart the frontend container:

docker-compose restart frontend

docs.title: Access Your Instance
docs.text: You should now be able to access Pantrie at https://pantrie.yourdomain.com!

docs.title: Connection Refused
docs.text:
• Verify Pantrie is running: docker-compose ps
  • Check nginx is listening: docker logs pantrie-nginx
  • Verify the tunnel is running: sudo systemctl status cloudflared

docs.title: 502 Bad Gateway
docs.text:
• Check that the port in your tunnel config matches your nginx container port
  • Verify nginx is properly configured: docker logs pantrie-nginx

docs.title: Vite Host Blocking Error
docs.text:
If you see "Blocked request. This host is not allowed":

  1. Add your domain to allowedHosts in frontend/vite.config.ts
  2. Restart the frontend container: docker-compose restart frontend

docs.title: Tunnel Not Starting
docs.text:
Check the cloudflared logs:

sudo journalctl -u cloudflared -f

Common issues: - Invalid tunnel ID in config.yml - Incorrect credentials file path - Port already in use

docs.title: Cloudflare Access (Optional)
docs.text:
For additional security, you can put Cloudflare Access in front of your application:

  1. Go to Cloudflare Zero Trust dashboard
  2. Create an Access policy for your domain
  3. Configure authentication methods (email OTP, Google, GitHub, etc.)

This adds an extra layer of authentication before users can reach your Pantrie login page.

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text:
Consider enabling Cloudflare's rate limiting to protect against brute-force attacks:

  1. Go to your domain in Cloudflare dashboard
  2. Navigate to Security > WAF
  3. Create rate limiting rules for your login endpoints

docs.title: Multiple Domains
docs.text:
You can route multiple domains through the same tunnel:

ingress:
  - hostname: pantrie.yourdomain.com
    service: http://localhost:80
  - hostname: inventory.yourdomain.com
    service: http://localhost:80
  - service: http_status:404

docs.title: Health Checks
docs.text:
Add health check configuration to your tunnel:

tunnel: <YOUR_TUNNEL_ID>
credentials-file: /home/<YOUR_USERNAME>/.cloudflared/<YOUR_TUNNEL_ID>.json

warp-routing:
  enabled: false

ingress:
  - hostname: pantrie.yourdomain.com
    service: http://localhost:80
    originRequest:
      connectTimeout: 30s
      noTLSVerify: false
  - service: http_status:404

docs.text:

docs.title: Docker Development Guide
docs.text: This guide covers running Pantrie in Docker for development.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Start all services
./scripts/docker-start.sh

# Visit http://localhost:5173 to access the application

docs.title: Services
docs.text:
The Docker setup includes:

  • PostgreSQL (port 5432) - Main database
  • Redis (port 6379) - Caching and real-time features
  • Backend (port 8000) - FastAPI application
  • Frontend (port 5173) - React + Vite development server

docs.title: Management Commands
docs.text:
# Start the environment
./scripts/docker-start.sh

# Stop all services (preserves data)
./scripts/docker-stop.sh

# View logs for all services
./scripts/docker-logs.sh

# View logs for a specific service
./scripts/docker-logs.sh backend
./scripts/docker-logs.sh frontend

# Open a shell in a container
./scripts/docker-shell.sh backend   # Opens bash in backend
./scripts/docker-shell.sh frontend  # Opens sh in frontend
./scripts/docker-shell.sh postgres  # Opens psql console
./scripts/docker-shell.sh redis     # Opens redis-cli

# Reset everything (WARNING: deletes all data!)
./scripts/docker-reset.sh

docs.title: Manual Docker Compose Commands
docs.text:
# Start services
docker-compose up -d

# Stop services
docker-compose down

# View logs
docker-compose logs -f

# Rebuild containers
docker-compose up -d --build

# Run migrations
docker-compose exec -T backend alembic upgrade head

# Access database
docker-compose exec -T postgres psql -U pantrie -d pantrie

docs.title: Volumes
docs.text:
Data is persisted in Docker volumes:

  • pantrie_postgres-data - Database data
  • pantrie_redis-data - Redis data
  • pantrie_backend-venv - Python virtual environment (for faster rebuilds)
  • pantrie_frontend-node-modules - Node modules (for faster rebuilds)

To completely remove all data: 

docker-compose down -v

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text:
1. First time setup: 

    ./scripts/docker-start.sh
    Visit http://localhost:5173 and complete the initial setup wizard.

  2. Daily development:

  3. Code changes in ./backend and ./frontend are automatically reloaded
  4. Backend: uvicorn --reload watches for Python file changes

  5. Frontend: Vite HMR provides instant updates

  6. Database changes: 

    # Create a new migration
docker-compose exec -T backend alembic revision --autogenerate -m "description"

# Apply migrations
docker-compose exec -T backend alembic upgrade head

  7. Viewing logs: 

    ./scripts/docker-logs.sh backend

  8. Resetting the database: 

    ./scripts/docker-reset.sh
./scripts/docker-start.sh

docs.title: Containers won't start
docs.text:
# Remove old containers
docker-compose down
docker rm -f pantrie-backend pantrie-frontend pantrie-postgres pantrie-redis

# Try again
./scripts/docker-start.sh

docs.title: Database connection errors
docs.text:
# Check if PostgreSQL is healthy
docker-compose ps

# View PostgreSQL logs
docker-compose logs postgres

# Restart just the backend
docker-compose restart backend

docs.title: Frontend not loading
docs.text:
# Check frontend logs
docker-compose logs frontend

# Rebuild frontend
docker-compose up -d --build frontend

docs.title: Port conflicts
docs.text: If ports 5173, 8000, 5432, or 6379 are already in use, you'll need to either: - Stop the conflicting service - Modify the ports in docker-compose.yml

docs.title: Performance Tips
docs.text:
1. Use volumes for dependencies - The setup already mounts node_modules and .venv as volumes for faster rebuilds

  2. Limit log size - Add to docker-compose.yml for each service: 

    logging:
  options:
    max-size: "10m"
    max-file: "3"

  3. Prune unused resources periodically: 

    docker system prune -a --volumes

docs.title: NGINX Proxy Manager
docs.text: NGINX Proxy Manager (NPM) is a user-friendly web interface for managing reverse proxy configurations with automatic SSL certificate generation via Let's Encrypt. It's an excellent choice for users who want more control than Cloudflare Tunnels while maintaining ease of use.

docs.title: What is NGINX Proxy Manager?
docs.text:
NGINX Proxy Manager provides:

  • Web-based GUI: No need to edit configuration files manually
  • Automatic SSL: Free Let's Encrypt SSL certificates with automatic renewal
  • Access Control: Built-in authentication and IP whitelisting
  • Custom Locations: Advanced routing rules and custom nginx configurations
  • Multiple Services: Manage multiple reverse proxy hosts from one interface

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A domain name with DNS pointing to your server's public IP
  • Port 80 and 443 open on your firewall/router
  • Docker and Docker Compose installed
  • Pantrie running via Docker Compose

docs.title: Option 1: Separate Docker Compose (Recommended)
docs.text:
Create a separate docker-compose.yml for NGINX Proxy Manager in its own directory:

version: '3.8'

services:
  app:
    image: 'jc21/nginx-proxy-manager:latest'
    container_name: nginx-proxy-manager
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - '80:80'      # HTTP
      - '443:443'    # HTTPS
      - '81:81'      # Admin UI
    environment:
      DB_MYSQL_HOST: "db"
      DB_MYSQL_PORT: 3306
      DB_MYSQL_USER: "npm"
      DB_MYSQL_PASSWORD: "npm"
      DB_MYSQL_NAME: "npm"
    volumes:
      - ./data:/data
      - ./letsencrypt:/etc/letsencrypt
    depends_on:
      - db

  db:
    image: 'jc21/mariadb-aria:latest'
    container_name: nginx-proxy-manager-db
    restart: unless-stopped
    environment:
      MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD: 'npm'
      MYSQL_DATABASE: 'npm'
      MYSQL_USER: 'npm'
      MYSQL_PASSWORD: 'npm'
    volumes:
      - ./mysql:/var/lib/mysql

networks:
  default:
    name: nginx-proxy-manager

Start NGINX Proxy Manager:

docker-compose up -d

docs.title: Option 2: Integrated with Pantrie
docs.text:
You can integrate NPM into Pantrie's docker-compose.yml, but you'll need to:

  1. Remove the nginx service from Pantrie's docker-compose.yml
  2. Change Pantrie's backend and frontend to not expose ports publicly
  3. Add NGINX Proxy Manager to the same compose file

Port Conflicts

If you integrate NPM with Pantrie, make sure to remove port 80 from Pantrie's nginx service to avoid conflicts.

docs.title: 1. Access the Admin Panel
docs.text:
Navigate to http://your-server-ip:81

Default credentials: - Email: admin@example.com - Password: changeme

Change Default Credentials

Immediately change the default email and password after first login!

docs.title: 2. Update Your Pantrie Docker Compose
docs.text:
Modify Pantrie's docker-compose.yml to remove port 80 from nginx (since NPM will handle external traffic):

# In your Pantrie docker-compose.yml
services:
  nginx:
    image: nginx:alpine
    container_name: pantrie-nginx
    # Remove the ports section or change to:
    # ports:
    #   - "8080:80"  # Use a different port for direct access
    volumes:
      - ./nginx/nginx.conf:/etc/nginx/nginx.conf:ro
    depends_on:
      - backend
      - frontend
    networks:
      - pantrie-network
      - nginx-proxy-manager  # Add this network

networks:
  pantrie-network:
    driver: bridge
  nginx-proxy-manager:
    external: true

Recreate the containers:

docker-compose up -d

docs.title: 1. Add a Proxy Host
docs.text:
In the NGINX Proxy Manager UI:

  1. Click Hosts → Proxy Hosts
  2. Click Add Proxy Host

docs.title: 2. Details Tab
docs.text:
Configure the following:

  • Domain Names: pantrie.yourdomain.com
  • Scheme: http
  • Forward Hostname / IP:
  • If using separate compose: Your server's IP or host.docker.internal
  • If integrated: pantrie-nginx (the container name)
  • Forward Port: 80 (or 8080 if you changed it)
  • Block Common Exploits: ✅ Enabled
  • Websockets Support: ✅ Enabled (recommended for future features)

docs.title: 3. SSL Tab
docs.text:
Configure SSL certificate:

  • SSL Certificate: Select "Request a new SSL Certificate"
  • Force SSL: ✅ Enabled
  • HTTP/2 Support: ✅ Enabled
  • HSTS Enabled: ✅ Enabled (recommended)
  • Email Address: Your email for Let's Encrypt notifications
  • I Agree to the Let's Encrypt Terms of Service: ✅

Click Save

docs.title: 4. Advanced Tab (Optional)
docs.text:
Add custom nginx configuration if needed:

# Increase timeouts for large uploads
client_max_body_size 50M;
proxy_connect_timeout 300s;
proxy_send_timeout 300s;
proxy_read_timeout 300s;

# Additional headers
proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
proxy_set_header Connection "upgrade";

docs.title: Update Vite Configuration
docs.text:
Update your frontend/vite.config.ts to allow your custom domain:

server: {
  port: 5173,
  host: '0.0.0.0',
  allowedHosts: [
    'localhost',
    '127.0.0.1',
    'pantrie.yourdomain.com',  // Add your domain
    '.yourdomain.com',         // Allow all subdomains
  ],
  // ... rest of config
}

Restart the frontend container:

cd /path/to/pantrie
docker-compose restart frontend

docs.title: Access Your Instance
docs.text: You should now be able to access Pantrie at https://pantrie.yourdomain.com!

docs.title: 502 Bad Gateway
docs.text:
Common causes:

  1. Wrong Forward Port: Verify you're using the correct port (80 or 8080)
  2. Container Not Running: Check Pantrie is running: docker-compose ps
  3. Network Issues: Ensure NPM can reach Pantrie's network
  4. Nginx Not Started: Check nginx logs: docker logs pantrie-nginx

docs.title: SSL Certificate Failed
docs.text:
1. Verify DNS is pointing to your public IP
  2. Ensure ports 80 and 443 are open and forwarded
  3. Check Let's Encrypt rate limits (5 certificates per domain per week)
  4. Review NPM logs: docker logs nginx-proxy-manager

docs.title: Cannot Access NPM Admin Panel
docs.text:
• Verify NPM is running: docker ps | grep nginx-proxy-manager
  • Check port 81 is not blocked by firewall
  • Try accessing via localhost: http://localhost:81

docs.title: Vite Host Blocking Error
docs.text:
If you see "Blocked request. This host is not allowed":

  1. Add your domain to allowedHosts in frontend/vite.config.ts
  2. Restart the frontend container: docker-compose restart frontend

docs.title: 1. Secure the Admin Panel
docs.text:
• Use a strong password
  • Consider changing the admin port from 81 to something non-standard
  • Add IP whitelist to the admin panel
  • Use Cloudflare or another DDoS protection service

docs.title: 2. Enable Access Lists
docs.text:
NPM supports access lists for additional authentication:

  1. Go to Access Lists
  2. Create a new list with authentication requirements
  3. Apply it to your Pantrie proxy host

docs.title: 3. Regular Updates
docs.text:
Keep NGINX Proxy Manager updated:

docker-compose pull
docker-compose up -d

docs.title: 4. Backup Configuration
docs.text:
Regularly backup the NPM data directory:

tar -czf npm-backup-$(date +%Y%m%d).tar.gz ./data ./letsencrypt

docs.title: Custom 404 Pages
docs.text:
Create a custom 404 page for proxy hosts:

  1. Go to 404 Hosts
  2. Add your 404 page configuration

docs.title: Stream Configuration (TCP/UDP)
docs.text:
NPM supports TCP/UDP streams for non-HTTP services:

  1. Go to Streams
  2. Configure TCP/UDP forwarding rules

docs.title: Custom Locations
docs.text:
Add custom location blocks for specific paths:

  1. Edit your Proxy Host
  2. Go to Custom Locations tab
  3. Add location-specific configurations

Example: Serve static files from a different location:

Location: /static/
Forward Hostname: static-file-server
Forward Port: 8080

docs.title: View Logs
docs.text:
Access NPM logs:

docker logs -f nginx-proxy-manager

docs.title: Access Logs
docs.text:
NPM stores access logs in the data directory:

tail -f ./data/logs/proxy-host-*.log

docs.title: Certificate Renewal
docs.text:
Certificates auto-renew 30 days before expiration. Check certificate status in the UI:

  1. Go to SSL Certificates
  2. View expiration dates and renewal status

docs.title: Comparison: NPM vs Cloudflare Tunnels
docs.text: Feature NGINX Proxy Manager Cloudflare Tunnels Setup Complexity Medium Easy Port Forwarding Required Yes (80, 443) No DDoS Protection No (unless behind CDN) Yes SSL Management Manual (Let's Encrypt) Automatic Multiple Services Excellent Good Custom Configuration Full control Limited Cost Free Free Best For Power users, multiple services Simple setups, home users

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Learn how to configure Pantrie for your environment.

docs.title: Backend Configuration
docs.text: The backend is configured using environment variables in the .env file located in the backend/ directory.

docs.title: Required Settings
docs.text:
# Database
DATABASE_URL=postgresql+asyncpg://pantrie:pantrie@localhost:5432/pantrie

# Security
SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key-here  # Generate with: openssl rand -hex 32

# Application
APP_NAME=Pantrie
ENVIRONMENT=development  # development, staging, or production

docs.title: CORS Origins
docs.text:
Configure which frontend URLs can access the API:

CORS_ORIGINS=["http://localhost:3000","http://localhost:5173","http://localhost:5175"]

docs.title: Redis Cache
docs.text:
Enable caching for improved performance:

REDIS_URL=redis://localhost:6379/0
REDIS_CACHE_TTL=3600  # 1 hour in seconds

docs.title: JWT Tokens
docs.text:
Customize authentication token expiration:

ACCESS_TOKEN_EXPIRE_MINUTES=30
REFRESH_TOKEN_EXPIRE_DAYS=7

docs.title: Open Food Facts
docs.text:
No API key required, but you can customize the URL:

OPEN_FOOD_FACTS_API_URL=https://world.openfoodfacts.org/api/v2

docs.title: OAuth Providers (Optional)
docs.text:
# Google OAuth
OAUTH_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
OAUTH_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret

# GitHub OAuth
OAUTH_GITHUB_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
OAUTH_GITHUB_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret

docs.title: Object Storage (Optional)
docs.text:
For image uploads using S3-compatible storage:

S3_ENDPOINT_URL=http://localhost:9000
S3_ACCESS_KEY_ID=minioadmin
S3_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=minioadmin
S3_BUCKET_NAME=pantrie-images
S3_REGION=us-east-1

docs.title: Email (Optional)
docs.text:
For sending notifications:

SMTP_HOST=localhost
SMTP_PORT=1025
SMTP_USER=
SMTP_PASSWORD=
SMTP_FROM_EMAIL=noreply@pantrie.app

docs.title: Frontend Configuration
docs.text: The frontend is configured using the .env file in the frontend/ directory.

docs.title: Available Settings
docs.text:
# API URL
VITE_API_URL=http://localhost:8000

# App Configuration
VITE_APP_NAME=Pantrie
VITE_APP_VERSION=0.1.0

# Feature Flags
VITE_ENABLE_GOOGLE_OAUTH=false
VITE_ENABLE_GITHUB_OAUTH=false

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
Production Security

Never use the default values in production!

  1. Generate a strong SECRET_KEY: 

    openssl rand -hex 32

  2. Use strong database credentials

  3. Enable HTTPS only
  4. Restrict CORS origins to your actual domain
  5. Set ENVIRONMENT=production

docs.title: Database
docs.text:
For production, consider:

  • Using a managed PostgreSQL service (AWS RDS, Google Cloud SQL)
  • Enabling connection pooling
  • Setting up regular backups
  • Configuring SSL connections
DATABASE_URL=postgresql+asyncpg://user:pass@db-host:5432/pantrie?ssl=require
DATABASE_POOL_SIZE=10
DATABASE_MAX_OVERFLOW=20

docs.title: Redis
docs.text:
For production caching:

  • Use managed Redis service
  • Enable persistence
  • Set appropriate TTL values
REDIS_URL=redis://redis-host:6379/0
REDIS_CACHE_TTL=3600

docs.title: Logging
docs.text:
The application uses structured logging. In production:

  • Logs are output in JSON format
  • Set appropriate log levels
  • Consider log aggregation services (CloudWatch, Datadog)

docs.title: Development
docs.text:
ENVIRONMENT=development
DEBUG=true
DATABASE_ECHO=true  # Log SQL queries

docs.title: Staging
docs.text:
ENVIRONMENT=staging
DEBUG=false
DATABASE_ECHO=false

docs.title: Production
docs.text:
ENVIRONMENT=production
DEBUG=false
DATABASE_ECHO=false

docs.title: Configuration Validation
docs.text:
The application validates configuration on startup. Check logs for:

  • Missing required variables
  • Invalid values
  • Connection issues

docs.title: Docker Configuration
docs.text:
When using Docker Compose, configuration is managed through:

  1. docker-compose.yml - Service definitions
  2. .env files - Environment variables
  3. Volume mounts - Persistent data

See Docker Deployment for details.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide will walk you through installing and setting up Pantrie on your local machine.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing Pantrie, ensure you have the following installed:

  • Python 3.11+
  • Node.js 18+ and npm
  • PostgreSQL 14+
  • Redis (optional, for caching)
  • Git

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
The fastest way to get started is using the provided setup scripts:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/untraceablez/pantrie-spec.git
cd pantrie-spec

# Run the quick start script
./scripts/quick-start.sh

This will: 1. Check all prerequisites 2. Set up the backend (virtual environment, dependencies, database) 3. Set up the frontend (dependencies) 4. Start both development servers

docs.title: Manual Installation
docs.text: If you prefer to install manually or the quick start script encounters issues:

docs.title: 1. Backend Setup
docs.text:
cd backend

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt
pip install -r requirements-dev.txt

# Copy environment template
cp .env.example .env

# Edit .env with your configuration
# Ensure DATABASE_URL points to your PostgreSQL instance

# Run database migrations
alembic upgrade head

# Start the backend server
uvicorn src.main:app --reload --port 8000

docs.title: 2. Frontend Setup
docs.text:
In a new terminal:

cd frontend

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Copy environment template
cp .env.example .env

# Start the development server
npm run dev

docs.title: 3. Database Setup
docs.text:
Create a PostgreSQL database:

CREATE DATABASE pantrie;
CREATE USER pantrie WITH PASSWORD 'pantrie';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON DATABASE pantrie TO pantrie;

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
After installation, verify everything is working:

  1. Backend should be running at http://localhost:8000
  2. Frontend should be running at http://localhost:5173
  3. API docs available at http://localhost:8000/api/docs

You can also run the verification script:

./scripts/verify-setup.sh

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
If you see errors about ports being in use:

# Check what's using port 8000
lsof -i :8000

# Kill the process
kill -9 <PID>

docs.title: Database Connection Issues
docs.text:
Ensure PostgreSQL is running:

# On macOS with Homebrew
brew services start postgresql

# On Ubuntu/Debian
sudo systemctl start postgresql

# On Windows
# Use the PostgreSQL service in Services app

docs.title: Python Virtual Environment Issues
docs.text:
If you have trouble with the virtual environment:

# Remove and recreate
rm -rf venv
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get up and running with Pantrie in minutes!

docs.title: First Time Setup
docs.text:
1. Register an Account
  2. Navigate to http://localhost:5173
  3. Click "Sign Up"
  4. Enter your email, username, and password

  5. Click "Register"

  6. Create Your First Household

  7. After logging in, click "Create Household"
  8. Enter a name (e.g., "My Home")

  9. Click "Create"

  10. Set Up Locations

  11. Navigate to Settings → Locations
  12. Add common locations:
    • Refrigerator
    • Freezer
    • Pantry
    • Kitchen Cabinet

docs.title: Method 1: Barcode Scanning
docs.text:
1. Click the "+ Add Item" button
  2. Click "Scan Barcode"
  3. Enter a barcode (e.g., 027271140013 for testing)
  4. Review the auto-filled information from Open Food Facts
  5. Select a location
  6. Add quantity and expiration date (optional)
  7. Click "Save"

docs.title: Method 2: Manual Entry
docs.text:
1. Click the "+ Add Item" button
  2. Click "Manual Entry"
  3. Fill in the item details:
  4. Name (required)
  5. Location (required)
  6. Quantity
  7. Unit
  8. Expiration date
  9. Notes
  10. Click "Save"

docs.title: View Inventory
docs.text:
• All Items: Main inventory page shows all items
  • Filter by Location: Use the location dropdown
  • Search: Use the search bar to find specific items
  • Sort: Click column headers to sort

docs.title: Update an Item
docs.text:
1. Click on any item card
  2. Click "Edit"
  3. Update the fields
  4. Click "Save"

docs.title: Mark Item as Used/Consumed
docs.text:
1. Click on the item
  2. Adjust the quantity
  3. Or click "Delete" to remove completely

docs.title: Setting Up Custom Allergens
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Settings → Household Settings
  2. Scroll to "Custom Allergens" section
  3. Click "Add Allergen"
  4. Enter allergen name (e.g., "peanuts", "soy", "dairy")
  5. Click "Add"

Items with matching ingredients will now show allergen warnings!

docs.title: Inviting Household Members
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Settings → Household Settings
  2. Find the "Members" section
  3. Click "Invite Member"
  4. Enter their email address
  5. Select their role:
  6. Viewer: Can view items only
  7. Editor: Can add/edit items
  8. Admin: Full access including settings

docs.title: Tips for Success
docs.text:
Barcode Scanning

Most grocery items have barcodes that work with Open Food Facts. This auto-fills nutrition data and allergen information!

Expiration Dates

Items close to expiration appear with colored indicators:

  • 🟢 Green: More than 7 days
  • 🟡 Yellow: 3-7 days
  • 🔴 Red: Less than 3 days or expired

Organization

Use locations to mirror your real-world storage. This makes it easy to find items when cooking or shopping.

Data Sync

Changes are saved immediately. All household members see updates in real-time.

docs.title: Grocery Shopping
docs.text:
1. Check inventory before shopping
  2. Add items as you unpack groceries
  3. Use barcode scanning for speed

docs.title: Meal Planning
docs.text:
1. Search for ingredients you have
  2. Check expiration dates
  3. Plan meals around items expiring soon

docs.title: Reducing Food Waste
docs.text:
1. Sort by expiration date
  2. Move items close to expiring to the front
  3. Plan meals to use them first

docs.title: Custom Allergens
docs.text: Learn how to set up and manage custom allergen tracking in Pantrie.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Custom allergens allow you to define household-specific dietary restrictions. Pantrie automatically checks item ingredients and displays warnings when allergens are detected.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Custom Allergen Lists: Define allergens specific to your household
  • Automatic Detection: Ingredients are checked against your allergen list
  • Visual Warnings: Clear alerts on items containing allergens
  • Open Food Facts Integration: Works alongside official allergen data
  • Word Boundary Matching: Accurate detection using intelligent pattern matching

docs.title: Adding Allergens
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Settings → Household Settings
  2. Scroll to the Custom Allergens section
  3. Click Add Allergen
  4. Enter the allergen name (e.g., "peanuts", "soy", "dairy")
  5. Click Add or press Enter

Common Allergens

Consider adding:

  • Peanuts
  • Tree nuts
  • Soy
  • Dairy
  • Eggs
  • Wheat/Gluten
  • Shellfish
  • Fish
  • Sesame

docs.title: Removing Allergens
docs.text:
1. Find the allergen in your list
  2. Click the × (delete) button
  3. Confirm removal

docs.title: Ingredient Matching
docs.text:
Pantrie uses intelligent matching to detect allergens:

Allergen: "peanut"
✅ Matches: "peanuts", "peanut butter", "roasted peanuts"
❌ Doesn't match: "pea" (word boundary protection)

docs.title: Case-Insensitive
docs.text:
Matching is case-insensitive:

Allergen: "dairy"
✅ Matches: "Dairy", "DAIRY", "dairy products"

docs.title: Word Boundaries
docs.text:
Uses word boundaries to avoid false positives:

Allergen: "soy"
✅ Matches: "soy sauce", "soy protein"
❌ Doesn't match: "soybeans" (unless you add "soybean" separately)

docs.title: Where Warnings Appear
docs.text: Warnings are shown in two places:

docs.title: 1. Inventory Card View
docs.text: Small allergen indicator appears on item cards when allergens are detected.

docs.title: 2. Item Detail Modal
docs.text:
Detailed allergen information shows:

  • Custom allergens detected in ingredients
  • Open Food Facts allergen data
  • Full ingredient list for review

docs.title: Warning Display
docs.text:
Allergen Detected: Peanuts

This item contains ingredients matching your custom allergens.

docs.title: Combined Allergen Data
docs.text:
Pantrie shows both:

  • Custom Allergens: Your household-specific list
  • Open Food Facts Allergens: Official allergen data from the product

Example display:

⚠️ Allergens Detected

Custom Allergens:
- Peanuts
- Soy

From Open Food Facts:
- Peanuts
- May contain traces of tree nuts

docs.title: Be Specific
docs.text:
Add both singular and plural forms if needed:

  • "peanut" AND "peanuts"
  • "nut" AND "nuts"

docs.title: Add Variations
docs.text:
Include common variations:

  • "milk" AND "dairy"
  • "wheat" AND "gluten"

docs.title: Review Ingredients
docs.text:
Always review the full ingredient list for accuracy. Automated detection is helpful but not a substitute for careful review.

Critical Allergies

For severe allergies, always manually review ingredient lists. Automated detection is a convenience tool, not a medical device.

docs.title: Keep Lists Updated
docs.text:
• Add new allergens as dietary needs change
  • Remove allergens no longer relevant
  • Review periodically with household members

docs.title: Text-Based Matching
docs.text:
• Only detects allergens mentioned in ingredient text
  • Cannot detect unlisted allergens
  • Depends on ingredient data quality

docs.title: Data Quality
docs.text:
• Accuracy depends on Open Food Facts data
  • Manual entries may not have ingredient lists
  • Some products may have incomplete data

docs.title: Not Medical Advice
docs.text:
Medical Disclaimer

This feature is for convenience only. Always:

  • Read product labels carefully
  • Consult with medical professionals
  • Verify information before consumption
  • Be aware of cross-contamination risks

docs.title: Who Can Manage Allergens
docs.text:
Only household Admins can:

  • Add custom allergens
  • Remove custom allergens
  • Modify the allergen list

docs.title: Who Can View Warnings
docs.text:
All household members can:

  • See allergen warnings
  • View which allergens are detected
  • Access full ingredient lists

docs.title: Allergen Not Detected
docs.text:
1. Check spelling: Ensure allergen name matches ingredient text exactly
  2. Add variations: Try adding both "peanut" and "peanuts"
  3. Review ingredients: Verify the item has ingredient data
  4. Check word boundaries: "soy" won't match "soybeans"

docs.title: False Positives
docs.text:
If you see incorrect matches:

  1. Remove the allergen temporarily
  2. Add more specific terms: "soy sauce" instead of just "soy"
  3. Report data issues to Open Food Facts if product data is wrong

docs.title: Missing Ingredient Data
docs.text:
If items don't have ingredients:

  • Manual entries may need ingredients added
  • Some barcoded items may have incomplete data
  • You can manually edit items to add ingredient information

docs.title: Example 1: Peanut Allergy
docs.text:
Setup: 

Custom Allergens:
- peanut
- peanuts
- peanut butter

Results: - ✅ Detects: "Contains peanuts" - ✅ Detects: "peanut butter" - ✅ Detects: "Roasted PEANUTS" - ❌ Misses: "groundnuts" (alternative name)

docs.title: Example 2: Dairy Free
docs.text:
Setup: 

Custom Allergens:
- milk
- dairy
- cream
- butter
- cheese
- whey
- casein
- lactose

Results: - ✅ Comprehensive coverage - ✅ Catches most dairy ingredients - ❌ May miss obscure dairy derivatives

docs.title: Integration with Open Food Facts
docs.text: Custom allergens complement Open Food Facts data:

docs.title: Open Food Facts Provides
docs.text:
• Official allergen declarations
  • May contain" warnings
  • Standardized allergen names

docs.title: Custom Allergens Add
docs.text:
• Household-specific restrictions
  • Additional ingredients to watch
  • Flexible matching

docs.title: Together They Offer
docs.text:
• Comprehensive allergen detection
  • Multiple layers of protection
  • Flexibility for unique dietary needs

docs.title: User Guide Overview
docs.text: Welcome to the Pantrie user guide! This section covers everything you need to know about using Pantrie effectively.

docs.title: What is Pantrie?
docs.text:
Pantrie is a household inventory management system that helps you:

  • Track food and household items
  • Monitor expiration dates
  • Reduce food waste
  • Manage multiple households
  • Track custom allergens
  • Scan barcodes for quick entry

docs.title: Households
docs.text:
A household is a shared inventory space. You can:

  • Create multiple households (e.g., "Home", "Vacation House")
  • Invite members with different permission levels
  • Manage settings per household

docs.title: Inventory Items
docs.text:
Items are what you track in Pantrie. Each item has:

  • Name: What the item is
  • Location: Where it's stored
  • Quantity: How much you have
  • Expiration Date: When it expires (optional)
  • Barcode: For quick identification (optional)
  • Nutrition Info: From Open Food Facts (optional)

docs.title: Locations
docs.text:
Locations organize your items by where they're stored:

  • Refrigerator
  • Freezer
  • Pantry
  • Cabinets
  • Custom locations

docs.title: Custom Allergens
docs.text:
Define allergens specific to your household:

  • Automatically checked against item ingredients
  • Visual warnings on items containing allergens
  • Works with Open Food Facts allergen data

docs.title: Viewer
docs.text:
• View all household items
  • Search and filter inventory
  • View item details
  • Cannot add or modify items

docs.title: Editor
docs.text:
• All Viewer permissions
  • Add new items
  • Edit existing items
  • Delete items
  • Cannot modify household settings

docs.title: Admin
docs.text:
• All Editor permissions
  • Manage household settings
  • Manage locations
  • Invite/remove members
  • Manage custom allergens
  • Transfer household ownership

docs.title: Main Dashboard
docs.text:
The dashboard shows:

  • Recently added items
  • Items expiring soon
  • Quick stats
  • Quick actions

docs.title: Inventory Page
docs.text:
View and manage all items:

  • Filter by location
  • Search by name
  • Sort by various fields
  • Add new items
  • Bulk actions

docs.title: Settings
docs.text:
Configure your household:

  • Household information
  • Locations management
  • Custom allergens
  • Member management
  • Personal settings

docs.title: Adding Items
docs.text:
Two methods:

  1. Barcode Scan: Fast, auto-fills data
  2. Manual Entry: Full control over details

docs.title: Finding Items
docs.text:
Multiple ways to search:

  • Text search by name
  • Filter by location
  • Sort by expiration date
  • View by category

docs.title: Managing Expiration
docs.text:
Color-coded indicators:

  • 🟢 Green: Fresh (7+ days)
  • 🟡 Yellow: Use soon (3-7 days)
  • 🔴 Red: Urgent (< 3 days)
  • ⚫ Gray: Expired

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
Regular Updates

Update quantities as you use items. This keeps your inventory accurate.

Scan Barcodes

Use barcode scanning whenever possible. It's faster and more accurate.

Set Expiration Dates

Even rough estimates help reduce waste. You'll get warnings as items age.

Organize Locations

Mirror your actual storage setup. Makes finding items easier.

Allergen Accuracy

Custom allergen matching is text-based. Review ingredient lists for accuracy.

docs.title: Mobile Usage
docs.text:
Pantrie is mobile-responsive:

  • Works in any modern browser
  • Add to home screen for app-like experience
  • Scan barcodes using phone camera
  • Quick add items while shopping

docs.title: Data and Privacy
docs.text:
• Data is stored securely
  • Only household members can see your inventory
  • You can export your data at any time
  • Deletion removes all your data
